title.narrative: Improving education and employment prospects for Jordanian and Syrian youth in the agri-food sectors through a connected and inclusive entrepreneurship programme

participating-org.narrative: International Centre for development oriented Research in Agriculture
International Centre for development oriented Research in Agriculture

mailing-address.narrative: P.O. Box 29777, 2502 LT The Hague, The Netherlands

title.narrative: Project photo
Narrative report

description.narrative: Reporting is an important management tool which is used to inform relevant government officials and other stakeholders about the results being achieved by individual projects and the programme as a whole. For project partners, it is compulsory to use the prescribed Orange Knowledge annual report format in order to report on project achievements. The annual report also provides valuable data on the financial situation of the project. Based on an analysis of the project performance in relation to the project output(s) and expected outcome(s), a revision of the project work plan may be suggested by the project partners. The consequences of a possible revision on the project work plan and budget must be made clear in the annual report. Nuffic monitors outputs and outcomes and not activities. Therefore, the main focus of the annual report must be on the achievement of the project’s output(s) and planned outcome(s). The information provided in the annual reports of the projects is used by Nuffic to monitor the progress of the project and to inform the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other stakeholders about the output(s) and outcome(s) being achieved by individual projects and the Orange Knowledge programme as a whole. Please note that if project progress is in accordance with the original planning, reporting requirements are minimal. Only in case of deviations from the planning, more elaboration is demanded. In the Grant Obligations and Conditions, the obligatory dates for submission of the annual/additional reports are mentioned. The final report must reflect on the entire project period.

title.narrative: 14. Final report TMT+/TMT

description.narrative:
Final conclusions TMT+/TMT (in case of final report) Reflect on how the training has contributed to addressing the capacity needs as described by the requesting organisation in the proposal form. How effective and efficient has the TMT+ been in reaching the desired objectives? Please formulate lessons learned and recommendations for the post-project period.
+
In your email submitting the final report, the partners will enclose: - an inventory of equipment purchased - a document signed by the (Lead partner) Dutch consortium/provider and Lead partner consortium country A or requesting organisation on the transfer of ownership - a list with the names and email addresses of staff members who participated in staff training for their registration in the Holland Alumni Network database

title.narrative: 2. Project progress and achievement

description.narrative:
In this section (maximum 1000 words), please
**For TMT+:**
Comment to what extent the outputs have been achieved. Comment on the activities that have taken place and the most important milestones.

title.narrative: 2. Project progress and achievement

In this section (maximum 1000 words), please

actual.value:
_Stakeholder engagement_
Following the project strategy, the Consortium engaged first with potential employers of graduates from JUST and performed a ++Labour Market Assessment++ to understand the demand of the agricultural sector in which JUST graduates would be seeking a job. COVID-19 slowed down the engagement process and affected the gathering of stakeholders. Two face-to-face meetings could be held with selected stakeholders; however, the main data collection had to be done through online meetings and online interviews.
After engaging with external stakeholders, the Consortium presented the findings to JUST staff and jointly identified training their training needs. This was done during a face-to -face session on 21 June at JUST University between consortium representatives of Advance Consulting and Luminus and JUST University representatives. Specifically training on pedagogical skills (such as virtual teaching) and training on engagement skills with the private sector were seen as areas where staff upskilling could take place.
_Training delivery_
++Making blended training work ++
4 staff members participated in an iCRA online course and were trained on:
· Making the perfect blend: mixing online and face-to-face group training, combining synchronous and asynchronous online learning
· Motivating & engaging trainees both online and face-to-face
· Linking learning to real-life situations
· Using tools for interactive and practical learning
++Training on engagement skills ++
4 staff members were trained on building relationships:
· Network mapping and strengthening relationships with the private sector
· Building trust with stakeholders, specifically listening skills, creating connections, and finding common ground
++Training on entrepreneurship++
8 staff members were familiarized with the theory and practice of entrepreneurship and small business management:
· Introduction to Entrepreneurship
· Theories of New Venture Creation
· Screening the Business Opportunity
· Creating Customers
· The Process of Planning and Strategy in the Small Firm

comment.narrative: 08-11-2021: See previous quote from JUST staff

title.narrative: B.I.2. % scholarship holder's /TMT participants / alumni satisfaction

comment.narrative: 08-11-2021: “The training course has provided us with very clear and easy to follow steps into making blended training a success. It was not regular training; it was like we got a personal trainer. Learning about the motivation start and the learning in steps facilitated positive learning outcomes. This training course helped us in embedding education in real life, offering teaching that goes beyond classroom walls that keeps students engaged and eager to learn. The training was eye-opening to the methods that can be applied in a blended course easily and applicable to the fields in agriculture and life sciences.” – Quotation from JUST staff

title.narrative: B.I.6. Number of stimulating measures/extra facilities aimed at preparation, supervision and aftercare of female candidates
B.O.1. Number of organisations strengthened by individual and/or group training
